ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about phonology, mainly OT, and how phonologists have modified it as different problems arose.

I learned a lot about Optimality Theory, which is an important theoretical framework in Phonology. I also enhanced my analytical and writing skills by completing the assignments and the final project.

How to analyze phonological alternations via rule based and OT frameworks (and of course, OT as a linguistic theory). Also how to work with natural language data, spot alternations, and be able to tell which ones will be interesting/ take work to accommodate with the existing theory, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really liked learning so many different facets of OT, and we were working mainly with journal articles etc. which was very beneficial. It was discussion-based, which was nice for some reasons but also a little difficult because I think I learn better from lecture-based, and I think the material was pretty dense so sometimes it was hard to learn things from primary literature instead of from lectures before reading the literature.
This course is excellent, and I don't think it has any kind of weaknesses in terms of the course structure.

I think the strengths of this course are that it encourages a high level of involvement. It pushes students to use critical thinking to solve problem sets (which had interesting datasets and questions), and to come up with novel analyses for the LP assignments. Some of the weaknesses lie in the structure of the class itself. Since OT was a new topic to me, I would have found it more useful for the class to be more lecture style, at least at the beginning, so we could spend more time on some of the core concepts of the theory. I think that the presence of student discussions form the start made it more difficult to get a full grasp of the framework itself. If more time was spent on basic concepts, we could have moved onto more higher level engagement later on in the class (like the discussion questions, critically engaging with the theory more). I would have also liked to read more of the foundational OT papers to see how the theory developed and changed. I also think timely feedback on the assignments (especially problem sets) would have helped with this issue as it would have helped me understand where I was going wrong in my implementation of OT/ what concepts I was misunderstanding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, mainly if they are excited about being proactive in their learning and learning things from readings/discussions instead of from lectures.
Yes, this course is important in the graduate curriculum and also crucial for undergrads who want a more comprehensive understanding of Phonology.
